content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays several fragments of fibro-adipose tissue, which is typical for a lymph node dissection specimen. Within these fragments, there are multiple well-circumscribed, basophilic (dark purple/blue) nodules of varying sizes. These nodules are characteristic of lymph nodes. I can identify at least four distinct potential lymph nodes. The overall impression is of pericolic fat containing multiple lymph nodes that need to be assessed for metastasis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because the green box highlights a well-defined, ovoid, basophilic structure that is unequivocally a lymph node based on its low-power appearance. When staging colorectal cancer, it is crucial to meticulously examine every lymph node to determine if cancer has spread (N staging). This particular node, being the first one from the bottom left, is a logical starting point for the microscopic examination to search for metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box is centered on a basophilic, cellular area within the largest tissue fragment, which is characteristic of a lymph node. As a pathologist staging a colorectal cancer case, my primary objective here is to determine the nodal (N) stage. This requires a thorough microscopic examination of every lymph node to identify any metastatic tumor deposits. I am zooming into this specific lymph node (the first one in the largest tissue piece) to assess its architecture and search for atypical epithelial cells that would indicate metastasis from the primary colorectal adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it contains a dense, basophilic (dark purple) cellular aggregate. At low power, such areas are highly suspicious for either being a lymph node or a tumor deposit. In a lymph node dissection specimen for colorectal cancer, identifying all lymphoid tissue is critical. This specific dark area needs to be examined at high magnification to first confirm if it is a lymph node and, more importantly, to meticulously search for atypical epithelial cells that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a dense, diffuse infiltrate of small, round cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of mature lymphocytes. There are small blood vessels interspersed throughout the lymphoid tissue. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, extensive necrosis, or other features that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is benign lymphoid tissue, representing a portion of a reactive or normal lymph node that is negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the interface between a lymph node and the surrounding pericolic tissue. On the right, there is a dense population of small, dark, round cells, which are lymphocytes, constituting the parenchyma of the lymph node. The lymphoid cells appear cytologically bland. On the left, there is mature adipose tissue and fibrous stroma. I do not see any evidence of metastasis in this field of view; there are no atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant cells, or mucin pools. My impression of this specific area is that it represents a portion of a reactive or normal lymph node that is negative for malignancy. I would proceed to examine the rest of this node and all other lymph nodes on the slide to confirm this finding.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see predominantly fibro-adipose tissue (fat cells and pink connective tissue). There is a distinct bundle of wavy, eosinophilic tissue with spindle-shaped nuclei, which is characteristic of a nerve bundle. Scattered within the adipose tissue are small clusters of dark, round cells consistent with lymphocytes. There are no definitive features of metastatic carcinoma in this specific field of view, such as atypical glands, large pleomorphic cells, or signet ring cells. My impression is that this area shows a small nerve bundle and a minor lymphoid aggregate within the pericolic soft tissue. This is not a classic lymph node structure and it appears negative for malignancy in this view. I would continue to scan the rest of the basophilic area and other tissue fragments.
